Violation_Type: Failure to adequately assess state protection
Legal_Issue: Whether the CRDD correctly assessed lack of state protection
Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, specifically provisions relating to convention refugee status
Application_Facts: Applicants faced threats, violence, and property damage due to religious conversion; reported incidents to police with no action taken
Decision_Outcome: CRDD dismissed claim based on insufficient evidence of police inaction
Court_Ruling: Federal Court allowed application, set aside CRDDâ€™s decision, remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Defendant_Behavior: CRDD dismissed claim citing insufficient evidence without sufficient analysis of state protection failure
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to religious conversion and lack of state protection
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee must show well-founded fear of persecution and inability to avail themselves of state protection
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicants' claims, responsiveness of state authorities, risk of harm
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (indirectly)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision by CRDD
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but CRDD questioned sufficiency of evidence regarding police inaction
Evidence_Used: Reports of threats, violence, property damage, and lack of police response
Legal_Provision_Cited: Definition of convention refugee under IRPA
Application_Basis: Religious persecution and absence of effective state protection in Russia
Evidence_Assessed: Incidents of violence and reports to police
Relief_Sought: Recognition as convention refugees, protection from removal to Russia
Governing_Rule: Under Canadian law, a refugee must demonstrate both persecution and lack of state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD found insufficient evidence of state inaction, though court found analysis inadequate
Outcome: Application allowed, decision set aside, matter remitted
Harm_Assessment: Risk of continued persecution due to religious identity in country of origin
Cause_Description: Applicants claimed persecution and lack of state protection in Russia due to religious conversion
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court found CRDD failed to properly analyze available evidence on state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Procedural fairness and proper application of refugee eligibility criteria under IRPA
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient consideration of police inaction despite documented reports
Legal_Provision: Section 97 and Section 98 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of CRDD decisions
Evidence_Assessment: CRDD's assessment deemed unreasonable for failing to engage with evidence of state inaction
Decision_Rationale: CRDD did not provide adequate reasons or analysis regarding availability of state protection
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of thorough evaluation of evidence on state protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution and inability to access state protection
